normalised: Question: What are some key things to keep in mind when drafting a rental agreement in India?

unnormalised: **Question: What are some key things to keep in mind when drafting a rental agreement in India?**
normalised: Hey everyone! Renting a place in India, be it in Mumbai or a cozy flat in Bangalore, involves a rental agreement. Don't just grab a standard template off the internet! Here's what I've learned:

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Renting a place in India, be it in Mumbai or a cozy flat in Bangalore, involves a rental agreement. Don't just grab a standard template off the internet! Here's what I've learned:
normalised: First, be very specific about the rent amount and the due date. No ambiguity! If it's rupee fifteen thousand, say rupee fifteen thousand and clearly state when it's due each month (e.g., "Rent of rupee fifteen thousand is due on the fifth of each month").

unnormalised: First, be VERY specific about the rent amount and the due date. No ambiguity! If it's Rs. 15,000, say Rs. 15,000 and clearly state WHEN it's due each month (e.g., "Rent of Rs. 15,000 is due on the 5th of each month").
normalised: Security deposit – nail this down! How much is it? (Usually two to three months' rent). More importantly, when and how will it be refunded? Include clauses for deductions, like for damages (beyond normal wear and tear).

unnormalised: Security deposit – nail this down! How much is it? (Usually 2-3 months' rent). More importantly, when and how will it be refunded? Include clauses for deductions, like for damages (beyond normal wear and tear).
normalised: Lock-in period is vital! If you plan to stay for at least a year (common in cities), mention it. And what happens if either you or the landlord (say, Mister Sharma) wants to break the lease? Include notice periods (usually thirty to sixty days). I once had a situation where my landlord tried to evict me with only twenty four hours notice back in two thousand and twenty, because his nephew needed the space. It wasn't legal because of the agreement.

unnormalised: Lock-in period is vital! If you plan to stay for at least a year (common in cities), mention it. And what happens if either you or the landlord (say, Mr. Sharma) wants to break the lease? Include notice periods (usually 30-60 days). I once had a situation where my landlord tried to evict me with only 24 hrs notice back in 2020, because his nephew needed the space. It wasn't legal because of the agreement.
normalised: Mention maintenance responsibilities clearly. Who pays for what? What about repairs beyond rupee five hundred? Put everything in writing!

unnormalised: Mention maintenance responsibilities clearly. Who pays for what? What about repairs beyond Rs. 500? Put everything in writing!
normalised: Finally, include details about any included amenities (like furniture, A C, etc.). and inventory. Also, include details about visiting times – the landlord can't just show up at three AM unannounced! Register your agreement before thirty first december two thousand and twenty four to ensure legality and address proof.

unnormalised: Finally, include details about any included amenities (like furniture, AC, etc.). and inventory. Also, include details about visiting times – the landlord can't just show up at 03:00 AM unannounced! Register your agreement before 31/12/2024 to ensure legality and address proof.
normalised: Get it reviewed by a lawyer if possible. It might cost a little, but it's worth it! And always keep a copy of the agreement! Good luck finding that perfect place!
